awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Thiol-ene/yne Poly(ionic liquid) Networks for Separation and Electroactive Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This RUI award supports fundamental research at Murray State University (MSU) in the area of electroactive materials while enhancing the education and training of undergraduate and high school students. The PIs will utilize a relatively novel, cost-effective, rapid-processing approach to prepare a library of polymers containing electrical charges with tunable thermal, mechanical, and conductive properties.  Such charge-containing polymers have been implemented in a number of societally important applications, including batteries, fuel cells, power plant flue-gas separations, and pharmaceutical materials. From the polymer-property relationships established as a result of this work, the principal investigators (PIs) will explore the applicability of these new materials in carbon dioxide separation/capture, ion-sensing devices, and in the formation of electroactive fibers. The challenging work proposed here will be performed primarily by a team of undergraduate students from the rural counties of far-western Kentucky and surrounding communities with participation also of local high school students. Student participants will receive a rewarding, cutting-edge research experience that will deepen their understanding of and appreciation for scientific research, thus better preparing them for STEM-related majors, careers and/or pre-professional school. In addition to the hands-on laboratory training and education that these students will receive, the PIs will explore how the techniques/data acquired from this proposal will be used to develop new laboratory experiments to supplement current course offerings in organic, analytical, and polymer chemistry,and will further enhance the new Polymer and Materials Science degree track offered by the Department of Chemistry at MSU. 



TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

This RUI award focuses on the development of a new class of poly(ionic liquid) (PIL) materials utilizing thiol-ene/yne click-photopolymerization with a strong focus on how changes in monomer structure and stoichiometry affect the thermal, mechanical, and conductive properties of the resulting PIL networks. The underlying hypothesis of this project is that thiol-ene/yne photopolymerization represents a significant advancement in the formation of solventless, one-part, homogeneous PIL networks due to the rapid and robust nature of the chemistry and the variability that exists with careful modification and selection of monomers. Specifically, fundamental structure-activity relationships will be established by varying the cation, anion, and thiol structures of the starting ionic liquid monomers and analyzing material properties such as glass transition temperature, thermal stability, crosslink density and ionic conductivity.  Additionally, FTIR experiments will be conducted in order to explore how structural changes affect polymerization kinetics, as well as dielectric relaxation spectroscopy to elucidate the roles that chain dynamics and ion mobility play on the conductivities of the networks. Once fundamental relationships and kinetics are established, the PIs will explore the potential impact of these thiol-ene/yne PIL materials on a variety of important applications, including carbon dioxide separation/capture, as microchip electrophoresis devices for support of electro-osmotic flow, as membranes in ion-selective electrodes,and as electroactive fibers from electrospinning. The award will support a large number of undergraduate STEM students from the far-western Kentucky region and several local high school students, thereby expanding the educational impact and outreach of the university and department while enhancing the ability of the participating students to pursue a STEM-related career. Synthetic approaches, materials analyses and applications will provide student participants with rewarding research experiences, all while generating results that will be disseminated in internationally recognized, peer-reviewed journals and presented at professional meetings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Charged polymers represent a unique class of materials that combine the attractive physical and electrochemical properties of the charged species with the mechanical stability of a polymeric architecture. This proposal sought to understand fundamental structure-property relationships in charged polymer networks using chemistry which can be accomplished simply with exposure to light.

Thiol-ene/yne click photochemistry offers a cost-effective, atom economical method for creating crosslinked polymer networks with variable thermal and mechanical properties. Upon inclusion of an ionic liquid (IL) group, we have successfully demonstrated that conductivity of the networks can also be varied by changing crosslink density and/or counteranion. The effect of humidity was also evaluated as several of the charged films exhibited enhanced conductivity at high humidity due to the creation of ion channels from water absorption. To date, four peer-reviewed publications in internationally recognized journals have been published, all of which focus on fundamental structure-activity relationships of thiol-ene/yne charged network polymers. In addition to these fundamental studies, our team has also investigated the applicability of the networks as membranes for ion-selective electrodes and gas (carbon dioxide) separation membranes, and 3D printing with the idea that this technology can be utilized in high performance applications such as energy storage, carbon dioxide sequestration, and additive manufacturing. Three collaborations have developed as a result of the work completed in this grant, one of which will focus on charged polymers in additive manufacturing and a second on further testing of our polymeric films in mixed gas separations. An additional collaboration with another undergraduate institution will focus on synthesizing cellulosic (bio-based/renewable) materials with ionic liquids, the details of which were recently funded by a new NSF-RUI grant.

A large number of students (16 undergraduates and 3 regional high school students) participated in this program over the four-year grant period. Over 50% of the participants were women and approximately 33% were first-generation college students. All of the student participants gained valuable experience in organic and polymer synthesis, as well as analysis and instrumentation, all of which will give them a distinct advantage as they pursue a job or further their education after Murray State University. To date, all twelve MSU student participants who have graduated have found employment or are in graduate/pre-professional school. All three high school students are pursuing undergraduate STEM-related degrees at MSU or elsewhere in Kentucky. Furthermore, all four peer-reviewed publications stemming from the intellectual aspects of this grant were co-authored by MSU undergraduate and/or high school students. Five student presentations at regional or national professional conferences were also given and four students completed their University Honors thesis. As our primary focus at Murray State is the education of our students, the PIs take great pride in being able to give these students the opportunity to gain this unique research experience.

As far as infrastructure is concerned, the PIs were able to obtain follow-on funding through the NSF (Major Research Instrumentation) to purchase a rheometer during this award period. This instrumentation has been critical in supporting a number of analytical measurements such as photorheology (the time that the material must be exposed to light in order to cure) and conductivity under anhydrous conditions. Furthermore, this grant has been utilized by the department and the college to recruit new students into our Polymer and Materials Science program. The population of this program has nearly tripled over the past three years. The MSU Polymer and Materials Science Laboratory, in addition to the new rheometer, has also seen upgrades over the past three years, with the college investing in a new TGA (thermogravimetric analyzer) and two melt rheometers acquired through donation from a local company.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2021
Modified by: Kevin M Miller
